Under special conditions one can obtain the minimal polynomial of certain endomorphisms instead of the characteristic polynomial. This may occur in the setting of an affinedomain $A$ and oneofitsNoethernormalizations $R=k[z_{1},\ldots,z_{d}]$ .For $u\in A$ thekernel of the homomorphism 
$$
R[t]\longrightarrow A,\quad t\longmapsto u,
$$
is an irreducible polynomial $h_{u}(t)$ (appropriately homogeneous if $A$ is a graded algebra and $u$ is homogeneous). It is related to the characteristic polynomial ${\hat{f}}_{u}(t)$ of $u$ by an equality of the form 
$$
f_{u}(t)=h_{u}(t)^{r}.
$$

Let $R$ be a commutative ring and $A$ a finite $R$ -module.An element $a\in A$ defines an endomorphism 
$$
f_{a}:A\longrightarrow A,f_{a}(x)=a x,
$$
of $R$ -modules.We seekwaystodefine the determinant of $f_{a}$ relative to $R$ .For example, if $A$ is a free $R$ -module,wemay use the standard definition.More generally,if $A$ hasafinitefree $R$ -resolution $\mathbb{H}$ 
$$
0\to F_{n}\longrightarrow\dots\longrightarrow F_{1}\longrightarrow F_{0}\longrightarrow A\to0,
$$
as above we lift $f_{a}$ to an endomorphism of $\mathbb{F}$ , and '‘define” $\operatorname*{det}(f_{a})$ as the alternating product 
$$
\operatorname*{det}(f_{a})=\prod_{i=0}^{n}\operatorname*{det}(f_{i})^{(-1)^{i}},
$$
